title: fastascan
text:
fastascan is the name of a tool that we had to create in the MSc in bioinformatics as an assignment for a Unix/algorithmics course. This was one midterm assignment after approximately 2 months using bash.
The purpose of this script is to design a tool that detects the .fa or .fasta files in an user-specified folder, does a summary of the files in the folder, and then an individual report containing the number of sequences, the number of amino acids/nucleotides in the whole file, specifying if the file is a symbolic link, and detecting if the file contains nucleotide or amino acid sequences.
The user can specify the folder to search in, and also if they want the first and last “n” lines of the file to be shown. If the number of lines of the file is smaller than 2n, the whole file is shown. The format to use the tool is fastascan [folder] [number_of_lines]. If the user doesn’t specify the folder to search, it will use by default the current directory. If the user doesn’t specify the number of lines, it won’t show any content of the file. If the 1st argument is an integer, and there is no 2nd argument, it will interpret the 1st as the number of lines that the user wants to see, and will search in the current directory.

title: fastascan
text:
Files
For an example, I created a folder with 4 different files (2 contain protein sequences in fasta format, 1 contains nucleic acid sequences in fasta format, and another one is a plain text without format). You can click them to see the content.

title: fastascan
text:
Output
This is the output of fastascan using the default settings (without specifying directory or number of lines, meaning that it will search in the current directory and not show any content from the files):


Click to toggle the output



suarezalvarez🐉 ~/sequences_example $ fastascan

!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!IMPORTANT INFORMATION!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
This program uses 2 arguments: the directory and the number of lines of each file to show.
If you only specify one of them, it will be interpreted as the number of lines if this argument is an integer, and as the directory if it is a text string.

This program considers a .fasta or .fa file to be a nucleotide (RNA or DNA) sequence if the content of A, C, T, G, U and N (upper or lower case) in the sequences contained in the file is greater or equal than 90%. If this condition is not fulfilled, the file will automatically be considered a protein sequence file.

This program considers the first word (delimited by spaces) after the ">" symbol in a fasta header as the identifier of the sequence.

================================================================
======================== SUMMARY ===============================
================================================================

Total number of .fasta and .fa files in the specified folders and its subfolders: 3
Number of unique fasta IDs: 10


================================================================
================== INDIVIDUAL REPORT ===========================
================================================================


========== /home/martin/sequences_example/Q9Y4U1.fasta [PROTEIN FASTA FILE] ==========
xx 1 protein sequence(s)
xx 282 amino acids in the sequences of this file
xx Not a symbolic link


========== /home/martin/sequences_example/cd40_seqs.fa [NUCLEIC ACID FASTA FILE] ==========
xx 8 nucleic acid sequence(s)
xx 12731 nucleotides in the sequences of this file
xx Not a symbolic link


========== /home/martin/sequences_example/Q9NZQ7.fasta [PROTEIN FASTA FILE] ==========
xx 1 protein sequence(s)
xx 290 amino acids in the sequences of this file
xx Not a symbolic link
```



And this is the output specifying the folder from my home folder, and specifying the number of lines.


Click to toggle the output


suarezalvarez🐉 ~ $ fastascan sequences_example/ 4

!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!IMPORTANT INFORMATION!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
This program uses 2 arguments: the directory and the number of lines of each file to show.
If you only specify one of them, it will be interpreted as the number of lines if this argument is an integer, and as the directory if it is a text string.

This program considers a .fasta or .fa file to be a nucleotide (RNA or DNA) sequence if the content of A, C, T, G, U and N (upper or lower case) in the sequences contained in the file is greater or equal than 90%. If this condition is not fulfilled, the file will automatically be considered a protein sequence file.

This program considers the first word (delimited by spaces) after the ">" symbol in a fasta header as the identifier of the sequence.

================================================================

title: About
text:
Hello, I’m Martín Suárez Álvarez, from Galicia and based in Barcelona. I’m a Biochemist and I’m currently studying a MSc in Bioinformatics for Health Sciences at Universitat Pompeu Fabra (Barcelona). I have great interest in omics data analysis, statistics, immunology, and cancer biology, and now I’m trying to learn about single cell/spatial technologies.
I want this website to be a place where I can upload the things that I do, both in class and in my free time, as a way of tracking my progress and share them with anyone who may be interested :)

title: Mastermind
text:
So this is the 1st post :) I wanted to share a piece of code that I did just for fun after discovering the board game Mastermind. In this case, the computer samples 5 times from a set of 8 colors with replacement, and the user will try to guess the colors that were chosen and their position. This is done in R, and visualized through 2 plots (using ggplot2) that are shown together using patchwork to simulate the actual board.
This is a Mastermind board, with 4 colors. If the player has guessed the position, it’s indicated with a red “pointer”, and if the player has guessed the color but not the position, it’s indicated with a white pointer.
In my case, I chose to play with 5 colors, unlimited opportunities, and black for the guessed position and white for the guessed color. This is an example of how the “board” looks using my code:

title: Mastermind
text:
Code
Here you can see the code. As a summary, I just created 2 functions: - The function reset(), that sets the number of tries to 1, samples 5 times from the colors, and sets everything to “default” to start a new game. - The function play(), that begins a player turn. It lets the player write the 5 colors, and will create a dataframe with the current play, and set the colors (black/white/grey) for the pointers depending on whether the positions and colors that the user chose are correct. Then, it will append this dataframe to the previous turns in the game dataframe. This allows for plotting all the turns together, having a global view of the play (it’s important for the development of the game).

# import packages
library(ggplot2)
library(patchwork)

# colors to sample from
colors = c('red', 'yellow', 'orange', 'pink', 'black', 'white', 'green', 'blue')

# create reset function: set number of tries to 0, sample colors, and save variables to global environment
reset = function() {
  cpu_cols = sample(colors, replace = TRUE, size = 5)
  game = data.frame(matrix(nrow = 0, ncol = 5)) # create empty "game" dataframe
  colnames(game) = c('try', 'cpu', 'player', 'pointer', 'pos')
  num_try = 1 # number of tries
  assign("cpu_cols", cpu_cols, envir = .GlobalEnv)
  assign("game", game, envir = .GlobalEnv)
  assign("num_try", num_try, envir = .GlobalEnv)
}

# create play function: let user choose 5 colors, update the "game" dataframe and plot the results
play = function() {
  # let player choose colors
  print("Choose color in position 1")
  col1 = readline()
  print("Choose color in position 2")
  col2 = readline()
  print("Choose color in position 3")
  col3 = readline()
  print("Choose color in position 4")
  col4 = readline()
  print("Choose color in position 5")
  col5 = readline()
  player_cols = c(col1, col2, col3, col4, col5)
  
  if (!(all(player_cols %in% colors))) {
    return(print("Insert a valid color"))
  }  # get error message if color is not valid
  
  # create dataframe of colors from cpu and player
  current_try = data.frame(
    try_num = rep(num_try, length(player_cols)),
    cpu = cpu_cols,
    player = player_cols,
    pointer = rep('grey', 5),
    pos = seq(1:length(player_cols))
  )
  
  num_try = num_try + 1 # update value of num_try
  assign("num_try", num_try, envir = .GlobalEnv) # save num_try to global env
  
  # checking if position is right and col is right
  black = 0
  white = 0
  for (i in seq(1:nrow(current_try))) {
    if (current_try$cpu[i] == current_try$player[i]) {
      black = black + 1
    } else if (current_try$player[i] %in% current_try$cpu) {
      white = white + 1
    }
  }
  
  if (black != 0) {
    current_try$pointer[1:black] = 'black' # correct positions
  }
  
  if (white != 0) {
    current_try$pointer[(black + 1):(black + white)] = 'white' # correct colors
  }
  
  game = rbind(game, current_try) # update game dataframe
  assign("game", game, envir = .GlobalEnv)
  
  # plot board
  player = game |> ggplot(aes(y = try_num, x = pos)) + 
    geom_point(size = 10, fill = game$player, col = 'black', pch = 21) +
    theme(panel.background = element_rect(fill = 'white'),
          panel.border = element_rect(color = 'black', fill = NA),
          text = element_text(size = 20)) + 
    scale_y_continuous(breaks = c(1:num_try), n.breaks = num_try) + 
    xlab('') +
    ylab('')
  
  pointer = game |> ggplot(aes(y = try_num, x = pos)) + 
    geom_point(size = 10, fill = game$pointer, col = 'black', pch = 21) +
    theme(panel.background = element_rect(fill = 'white'),
          panel.border = element_rect(color = 'black', fill = NA),
          text = element_text(size = 20)) + 
    scale_y_continuous(breaks = c(1:num_try), n.breaks = num_try) + 
    xlab('') +
    ylab('# Try')
  
  list_for_end = list(pointer + player & plot_layout(guides = 'collect'), "You won") # winning output
  
  if (all(current_try$pointer == c(rep('black', 5)))) {
    return(list_for_end) # winning message
  }
  
  return(pointer + player & plot_layout(guides = 'collect')) # return plots
}

# Initialize the game
reset()

# Start playing
play()

[1] "Choose color in position 1"

[1] "Choose color in position 2"

[1] "Choose color in position 3"

[1] "Choose color in position 4"

[1] "Choose color in position 5"

[1] "Insert a valid color"

title: Welcome To My Blog
text:
This is the first post in a Quarto blog. Welcome!

Since this post doesn’t specify an explicit image, the first image in the post will be used in the listing page of posts.
